headline.main: Tricks, Treats And Insulin; Moderation and Alternatives Save Halloween for Diabetics

docs.lead_paragraph: Like American youngsters everywhere, Natalie Fontana, an eighth grader from Cliffside Park, N.J., is counting down the hours to Halloween. Her costume is all ready -- a Marilyn Monroe number, complete with wig and high heels. Her trick-or-treating buddies are lined up. And her game plan -- namely the accumulation of obscene amounts of sweets -- is in place. ''I'm such a candy fanatic, I don't care what kind it is,'' she said.
docs.snippet: Health professionals and families have worked hard to turn Halloween into a day that children with diabetes can take delight in, not simply endure.
